In this section, we describe the computation of class average feature norm. To facilitate our discussion, we enumerate key notations in Table 1.
In a federated learning scenario for image classification tasks involving nğ‘›n participants, each participant Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} possesses a local dataset denoted as Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} with nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} labeled samples:

Metrics for performance evaluation are presented in Table 3, where the Tâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹fâ€‹fâ€‹iâ€‹cğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘Traffic represents the cumulative data exchanged, including both uploads and downloads, and Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’Time computes the duration to complete 10 rounds of training.
The metrics Îº=Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹uâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹yâˆ—104/Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğœ…ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¦superscript104ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’\kappa=Accuracy*{10^{4}}/Time and Ï=Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹uâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹yâˆ—104/Tâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹fâ€‹fâ€‹iâ€‹cğœŒğ´ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¦superscript104ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘\rho=Accuracy*{10^{4}}/Traffic were computed to measure test accuracy per unit of time and traffic, respectively, providing a quantifiable representation of efficiency and data economy of each algorithm.
Among tested FL algorithms, FNR-FL stands out for its exceptional efficiency in non-i.i.d scenarios, such as a Îºğœ…\kappa of 1.6462 and a ÏğœŒ\rho of 1.1184 in feature distribution skew. This overarching superiority of FNR-FL stems from its robust algorithmic structure that ensures high accuracy without disproportionately increasing communication or computational cost.

references: In more realistic and challenging settings, where data distributions are often mixed, we evaluated the performance of federated learning algorithms on the CIFAR-10 dataset under combined scenarios of label and feature distribution skew as well as label and quantity distribution skew. Our findings are summarized in Table 4.

S6.T5.caption: Table 5: Orthogonality of FNR-FL with existing FL algorithms (ResNet-18, CIFAR-10)
S6.T5.table:
Non-i.i.d scenarios Feature distribution skew Label distribution skew Quantity skew
FedAvg+FNR-FL 0.9976 0.9970 0.9982
FedProx+FNR-FL 0.9784 0.9838 0.9999
SCAFFOLD+FNR-FL 0.9783 0.9892 0.9637
MOON+FNR-FL 0.9678 0.9774 0.9532
FedNova+FNR-FL 0.9664 0.9766 0.9427
references:
The experimental results in Table 5 demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating the FNR-FL algorithm with other FL algorithms.
Across all scenarios, combinations involving FNR-FL consistently outperform their standalone FL algorithms, indicating a substantial enhancement in handling non-i.i.d data distributions. Specifically, FedAvg+FNR-FL emerges as a top performer in feature and label distribution skews, achieving accuracies of 0.9976 and 0.9970 respectively, while FedProx+FNR-FL leads in the quantity skew scenario with an accuracy of 0.9999. These results suggest that FNR-FLâ€™s regularization mechanism effectively complements and augments existing FL algorithms [34].

S6.T6.table:
Non-i.i.d setting Noise FNR-FL FedAvg FedProx SCAFFOLD MOON FedNova

references:
The experiment evaluates the performance and robustness of FNR-FL against other FL algorithms across different noise levels within feature and label distribution skews. The results are presented in Table 6.
In the feature distribution skew, FNR-FL consistently maintains the highest accuracy, indicating a strong resilience to noise. With a standard deviation (SD) of 0.0 (no noise), FNR-FL achieves near-perfect accuracy (0.9995), significantly outperforming the next best algorithm, SCAFFOLD, by a margin of 7%. As noise increases (SDs of 0.1 and 0.5), FNR-FL notably sustains a lesser degree of decline relative to other algorithms.
A similar pattern is observed in label distribution skew scenarios.
These findings suggest that FNR-FL is robust against noise in the data. This resilience to noise highlights the algorithmâ€™s potential for practical deployment in federated learning scenarios [38].
